bibl.note: This is a letter from Mary House to her husband George. It is dated February 1, 1846. Mary is aboard the steamboat Old Hickory in the Cumberland River. She writes about the trip so far. She mentions visiting an iron works, and that Mr Yerger has been organizing some entertainment. She writes that Susan and Sally are having a good time, and that Sally is the favorite.

div1.p:
Sunday morning half past 11 oclock finds us still in the Cumberland River — We are now taking in freight at Edyville, we landed here at daylight this morning and will remain here untill dark , we do not expect to leave this rever untill monday evening, if so, we will not reach Vicksburg before Friday — The Packet arrived this morning from Nashville with Passengers for this Boat, if I had known this sooner I could have remained in Nashville untill Saturday, and still have gon on the Hickory — We had some difficulty in passing the shoals — we reached Clarksville Friday morning a 6 oclock and staid untill 4 pm we were a ground about an hour — we have not traveled any at night yet — We left Nashville with about 90 pasengers , and our number has been increasing all the way, we have 25 or 30 laddies ladies, but I do not pretend to count the children Sally is the smallest except one, and is the favorite with all; particularly the Gentlemen and boys — Our company is a mery one — Mr Yerger is the life of all — he got up
a dance last night, and several plays — The Boat stopped at Stackers Iron Works yesterday we went on shore to see them making Iron It is quite a curiosity to witness it — Susan is well and enjoying her self very much — Sally is well — and makes her self entirely at home The first night we staid on board — (about the time you got home) she called out — several times; Gorge; Gorge; and then said Gorge gone; she talks about her Grand ma, and lines "Baby", — I may write again from Memphis but probably not untill I get to Clinton — Remember me to Mrs E Mrs P and the girls, tell martha; and Irene; that the girls did not come on bord — Jane Wilkins was in the country, and did not get Mr Yerger's letter Give my love to Ma, and the boys — Susan sends her love to all —
